entities.name: Bensalem
entities.definition: Island polity where inhabitants live in peace, friendship, and charity, isolated by laws of secrecy

evidence.quote: We of this island of Bensalem, have this; that by means of our solitary situation; and of the laws of secrecy, which we have for our travellers, and our rare admission of strangers; we know well most part of the habitable world, and are ourselves unknown

entities.name: Salomon's House
entities.definition: Scientific college dedicated to study of works and creatures of God, called the 'noblest foundation' and 'lanthorn of this kingdom'

evidence.quote: The end of our foundation is the knowledge of causes, and secret motions of things; and the enlarging of the bounds of human empire, to the effecting of all things possible

entities.name: Merchants of Light
entities.definition: Twelve fellows who sail into foreign countries under names of other nations to gather books, abstracts, and patterns of experiments

evidence.quote: We have twelve that sail into foreign countries, under the names of other nations, (for our own we conceal); who bring us the books, and abstracts, and patterns of experiments of all other parts. These we call Merchants of Light

entities.name: Interpreters of Nature
entities.definition: Three fellows who raise discoveries by experiments into greater observations, axioms, and aphorisms

evidence.quote: Lastly, we have three that raise the former discoveries by experiments into greater observations, axioms, and aphorisms. These we call Interpreters of Nature

entities.name: William Rawley
entities.definition: Bacon's chaplain, friend, and literary executor who published New Atlantis posthumously in 1627

evidence.quote: Bacon's literary executor, Dr. Rowley, published "The New Atlantis" in 1627, the year after the author's death

entities.name: Oxford Francis Bacon Project
entities.definition: Major scholarly project producing new 16-volume critical edition to replace Victorian Spedding edition

evidence.quote: The Oxford Francis Bacon project aims to produce a new 16-volume critical edition of the works of Francis Bacon (1561–1626), the Elizabethan-Jacobean lawyer, natural philosopher, and statesman

entities.name: David Colclough
entities.definition: Professor of Renaissance Studies at Queen Mary University of London, editor of New Atlantis in Oxford Francis Bacon XIX

evidence.quote: David Colclough's detailed Introduction sets New Atlantis in the contexts of Bacon's works and of contemporary models of information-gathering and -management

entities.name: Plato's Atlantis
entities.definition: Classical Atlantis narrative from Timaeus and Critias providing mythological template for Bacon's utopia

evidence.quote: The story, set in the present but against the background of Plato's account of Atlantis, and incorporating important classical, biblical and Christian elements

entities.name: More's Utopia
entities.definition: Renaissance utopian precedent establishing literary tradition of ideal commonwealth description

evidence.quote: His Lordship thought also in this present fable to have composed a frame of Laws, or of the best state or mould of a commonwealth

morphisms.statement: Rawley posthumously published New Atlantis containing Bacon's model of scientific college

evidence.quote: a fable my lord devised, to the end that he might exhibit therein a model or description of a college, instituted for the interpretation of nature

morphisms.statement: Oxford project produces Colclough edition as volume XIX of critical series

evidence.quote: This volume comprises the first critical edition since the nineteenth century of New Atlantis... David Colclough's detailed Introduction

morphisms.statement: Salomon's House serves as the very eye and lanthorn of Bensalem kingdom

evidence.quote: which house, or college (my good brethren) is the very eye of this kingdom

morphisms.statement: Merchants of Light gather raw materials ultimately processed by Interpreters of Nature

evidence.quote: We have twelve that sail into foreign countries... Lastly, we have three that raise the former discoveries by experiments into greater observations, axioms, and aphorisms

morphisms.statement: Plato's Atlantis provides mythological template and narrative framework for Bacon's Bensalem

evidence.quote: The story, set in the present but against the background of Plato's account of Atlantis

olog.name: Bacon's New Atlantis: Conceptual and Rhetorical Inheritance

conceptual.description: Epistemic Infrastructure: Experiment → Collection → Synthesis → Publication → Utility
axioms: Systematic experiment yields reliable natural knowledge through institutional organization
Collaborative research surpasses individual inquiry in scope and accuracy
Scientific secrecy balances public benefit with institutional preservation

institutional.description: Organizational Logic: College → Office → Governance → Ethos → Secrecy
axioms: Hierarchical division of labor optimizes knowledge production efficiency
Institutional isolation preserves scientific integrity from external corruption

interpretive.description: Scholarly Descent: Plato → Bacon → Colclough → Modern Readings
axioms: Editorial apparatus mediates between historical text and contemporary interpretation
Critical editions transform textual authority through scholarly intervention

rules: IF foreign knowledge is systematically gathered THEN domestic synthesis becomes possible
IF experiments are methodically organized THEN axioms and aphorisms emerge
IF scientific institutions maintain secrecy THEN external independence is preserved
IF editorial projects recontextualize texts THEN new interpretive possibilities arise

evidence.quote: The end of our foundation is the knowledge of causes, and secret motions of things; and the enlarging of the bounds of human empire, to the effecting of all things possible
We have consultations, which of the inventions and experiences which we have discovered shall be published, and which not: and take all an oath of secrecy
This volume comprises the first critical edition since the nineteenth century of New Atlantis

omissions: TLS review by Chloë Houston could not be accessed for modern interpretive framework
Colclough's Ethics and Politics essay unavailable for secondary analysis
Missing specific analysis of Sylva Sylvarum relationship to New Atlantis
overreach: May infer systematic institutional logic beyond explicit textual warrant
Could suggest editorial influence on interpretation without direct evidence of causation
corrections: Add entity for 'Feast of the Family' from Gutenberg § Family Customs with quote about Tirsan authority
Include morphism between 'Sylva Sylvarum' and 'New Atlantis' as 'twinned with' based on FBRT § Publishing History
Expand axiom about collaborative research with Gutenberg § 'Merchants of Light' evidence for systematic collection
